ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the theoretical applications behind statistics in the first half of the course, understanding WHY certain tests were used and what they meant; the second half of the course, the theoretical applications of the statistics became more difficult to understand and I mostly learned about the use of the online Statpack JMP which we learned to use. Interesting knowledge about pottery inclusions, hafting techniques used on arrow shafts, and Mongolian khirigsuurs (and other fabulous stories regarding Professor Honeychurch's life and research).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Engaging teaching style. Interesting problems to solve. Returning problem sets would be helpful...student graders were helpful but often failed to return graded problem sets.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. However, a student wishing to take this class should definitely have experience in archaeology. Little mathematics preparation is required but knowledge of archaeological techniques and vocabulary is strongly encouraged. The final paper requires application of statistics using real data gleaned from personal projects or colleagues' projects.
